<a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/clk/479706982;279358904;i" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="eToro" style="width:100%;max-width: 100px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="100" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby81NC8xNTc2MDc3MTk2LTE1NTcxODAzNDEuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0IjoiY29tZXQtbW9ybmluZ2JyZXciLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ=="></a>

<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>There’s a lot of darkness in the world, so let’s start off with a <a href="https://twitter.com/Aerocles/status/1321197402901065729/photo/1" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">message</a> from a school superintendent that was making the rounds on Twitter:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">“We have decided that few childhood acts remain unchanged due to COVID-19 and <span style="text-decoration: underline;">we will maintain the hope of children by calling actual snow days due to inclement weather</span>. Snow days are chances for on-site learners and virtual learners to just be kids by playing in the snow, baking cookies, reading books, and watching a good movie.” </p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PUBLIC HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/27/vaccine-scene-things-stand-oct-27?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Checking in on the Vaccine Scene
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A clock with syringes for hands " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTIwL3ZhY2NpbmVfY2xvY2suanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hey, you. Looks like you’re making some cool, spiky shots in there. How’s it going? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">AstraZeneca: </strong>Better than it was. We had suspended our late-stage vaccine trial after a participant developed neurological symptoms. But this week we <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2020/10/23/covid-19-vaccine-trials-from-astrazeneca-johnson-johnson-to-restart/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">restarted</a> it when independent monitoring committees and international regulators agreed that it was safe to resume. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Johnson & Johnson: </strong>Same here; we’re back up and running after a reported stroke incident in a volunteer. Outside experts and the FDA sniffed around and said we’re good to go. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>FYI, our vaccine is the only one being tested that involves a single dose.  </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Pfizer: </strong>Optimistic. The current trial with BioNTech <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/fauci-vaccines-will-only-prevent-symptoms-not-block-the-virus-195051568.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could reveal</a> our vaccine's effectiveness by late November, which would be the first from any vaccine candidate. We could potentially get emergency authorization by the end of the year. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Still, we </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pfizer-results/pfizer-says-no-covid-19-vaccine-data-yet-could-be-week-or-more-before-it-reports-idUSKBN27C1GT?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">just barely beat</a></span><span> Q3 earnings estimates yesterday. Our costs were down, but sales fell 4% thanks to people’s continued reluctance to go to the doctor—i.e. fewer prescriptions for our drugs. It’s not just us; they’re </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-27/slow-covid-recovery-stalks-health-industry-as-new-cases-surge?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">having the same problem</a></span><span> over at Eli Lilly. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Herd immunity: </strong>Stock is down. Doctors don’t know yet if antibodies = immunity, but it may not matter. A study published Monday <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/study-shows-covid-19-antibodies-waning-over-time-suggesting-immunity-may-wear-off-11603757012?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">showed</a> the number of people with antibodies dropped significantly (27%) in a three-month period, indicating that any immunity could be temporary. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The study hasn’t been peer reviewed yet. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The U.S.’ vaccine game is high-stakes. Any slip-ups in the program—such as only four out of six candidates proving effective, or not enough people getting vaccinated—<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-27/all-in-push-for-vaccine-in-u-s-raises-risk-virus-will-linger?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could mean</a> we’ll be dealing with the virus well into 2023. But if everything goes smoothly, we could turn the tide by July of next year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ FYI: </strong>On Monday, Dr. Anthony Fauci told Yahoo Finance that the “primary endpoint” of a vaccine is “to prevent clinically recognizable disease,” aka stamping out symptoms, rather than eliminating the virus entirely.</p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/27/eyepopping-numbers-news?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When you read every news story published, some numbers stand out. Here's a roundup from yesterday: </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1.4 billion: </strong>That's how many face masks 3M <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/3m-sales-rise-from-personal-safety-home-improvement-products-11603798292?mod=hp_lead_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">has sold</a> so far this year, per its earnings report. The manufacturer is aiming to make 2.4 billion N95 masks annually by the end of the year, which would more than triple its capacity before the pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">95%: </strong>the year-over-year drop in the number of finishers of timed races between mid-March and mid-October 2020, according to racing platform Athlinks. With major running events canceled all over the world due to the pandemic, the industry is facing its <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronaviruss-toll-on-marathons-and-other-races-a-95-drop-11603800000?mod=hp_listc_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">greatest crisis</a> in history, the WSJ writes. New York City's (canceled) marathon was supposed to take place this weekend.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1: </strong>There was only one chain in the Restaurant Brands International portfolio (Burger King, Tim Hortons, etc.) to report positive same-store sales growth last quarter...can you guess which one? Popeyes, whose iconic fried chicken sandwich is still causing traffic jams in the drive-thru lane. Comparable sales at Popeyes <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/27/restaurant-brands-international-qsr-q3-020-earnings-top-estimates.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">grew 17.4%</a> in Q3. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PUBLIC HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/27/governments-test-shorter-quarantines-improve-compliance?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When It Comes to Quarantines, Be a Karen
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A meme of Karen from Mean Girls on the phone saying " I can't go out *couch* I'm sick"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTI1L21lYW5fZ2lybHMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mean Girls</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In case Halloween candy sales in July didn't get the point across, humans are bad at sticking to schedules. Which is why a handful of governments are <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/countries-try-shorter-covid-19-quarantines-in-bid-to-boost-compliance-11603791001?mod=hp_lead_pos6&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shortening quarantines</a> in hopes that more people will actually start complying, the WSJ reports. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>14-day quarantines were reduced to seven days in France, while Belgium, Spain, and Germany are cutting them to 10. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Canada, Thailand, and the U.S. are also considering chopping quarantines for international visitors.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Is this a good idea? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The short answer is, scientists don't have enough data to know. But people aren't following quarantines, and health officials want to try something.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The standard 14-day quarantine isn't perfect science, either. The WHO says the average coronavirus incubation period (time from exposure to feeling sick) is 5–6 days, but for some cases it can take as long as two weeks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>with turkey season around the corner, quarantines are more important than ever. Yesterday, NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio <a href="https://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/politics/2020/10/27/mondays-with-the-mayor-bill-de-blasio-holiday-travel-message?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">asked</a> New Yorkers to avoid holiday travel. And many colleges <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/18/spring-break-coronavirus-colleges-429924?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">are sending</a> students home from campus after Thanksgiving, extending winter break, and scrapping spring break to reduce travel during flu season. </p>

<!--[if mso]>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>This article is part of our weeklong series exploring state-level issues in the upcoming election. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you had a sneaking suspicion that everyone cool you know is moving to Austin, TX, you're kinda right: Austin and other Texas metropolitan areas—Houston, Dallas, Fort Worth, and San Antonio—have collectively <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/texas-election-demographics-trump/2020/10/17/c952f440-108e-11eb-b1e8-16b59b92b36d_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">grown by 19%</a> from 2010 to 2018. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Why?</strong></span><span> Texas's cities are good for businesses. The WSJ ranked Austin the </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/24/austin-tx-tops-wsj-rankings-hottest-us-job-markets?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hottest job market</a></span><span> in the U.S. for the second straight year in 2019. And tech companies like Apple and Tesla are building new offices and factories in the city like it's their own personal Minecraft server. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What it means for Election Day</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Data compiled by the University of Houston shows that Texas's major metropolitan areas now account for 69% of the statewide vote, up from 52% in 1968. With cities filling fast with young tech workers who broadly lean left, the onetime Republican stronghold has gradually drifted into <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/politics/texas-political-geography/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">swing state</a> territory. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>It would still take a historic upswell of Democratic support to flip the state in this election. But as new job seekers continue to reshape its economic landscape, Texas and its meaty 38 electoral college votes might be up for grabs when 2024 rolls around.  </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TOURISM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/27/kazakhstans-tourism-board-channels-borat-new-marketing-slogan?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Kazakh Stans Borat
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Kazakhstan" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTIyL2themFraHN0YW4uanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Kazakh Tourism</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This week, Kazakhstan's tourism board released a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/26/business/kazakhstan-embraces-borat.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new advertising campaign</a>, "Very nice," to capitalize on the buzz around the new <em>Borat </em>sequel.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Borat, a fictional Kazakh journalist played by Sacha Baron Cohen, has the kind of backward ideas you don't want people associating with your country. So when the original <em>Borat </em>film came out in 2006, the government banned the movie and tried to explain Kazakhstan is actually <em>not </em>a cluster of medieval hamlets, as the film would have you believe.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The nowstory: </strong>Kazakh Tourism released a series of <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eRGXq4t9wY4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">12-second video spots</a> that use Borat's famous catchphrase (well, the only G-rated one) to describe the central Asian country's attractions. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>"Kazakhstan's nature is very nice, its food is very nice, and its people, despite Borat's jokes to the contrary, are some of the nicest in the world," Kairat Sadvakassov, deputy chairman of Kazakh Tourism, said in a statement.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This story reminds us of some other controversial tourism slogans. Rhode Island broadcasted itself as "<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/07/us/a-new-rhode-island-slogan-encounters-social-medias-wrath.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Cooler and Warmer</a>" in 2016; two years later, Nebraska <a href="https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2018/oct/18/honestly-its-not-for-everyone-says-nebraskas-self-/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a>, "Honestly, it's not for everyone."  </p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca Scene\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A clock with syringes for hands \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHey, you. Looks like you’re making some cool, spiky shots in there. How’s it going? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAstraZeneca: \u003c/strong\u003eBetter than it was. We had suspended our late-stage vaccine trial after a participant developed neurological symptoms. But this week we \u003ca href=\"https://www.statnews.com/2020/10/23/covid-19-vaccine-trials-from-astrazeneca-johnson-johnson-to-restart/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erestarted\u003c/a\u003e it when independent monitoring committees and international regulators agreed that it was safe to resume. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eJohnson \u0026 Johnson: \u003c/strong\u003eSame here; we’re back up and running after a reported stroke incident in a volunteer. Outside experts and the FDA sniffed around and said we’re good to go. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFYI, our vaccine is the only one being tested that involves a single dose.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePfizer: \u003c/strong\u003eOptimistic. The current trial with BioNTech \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/fauci-vaccines-will-only-prevent-symptoms-not-block-the-virus-195051568.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecould reveal\u003c/a\u003e our vaccine's effectiveness by late November, which would be the first from any vaccine candidate. We could potentially get emergency authorization by the end of the year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eStill, we \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pfizer-results/pfizer-says-no-covid-19-vaccine-data-yet-could-be-week-or-more-before-it-reports-idUSKBN27C1GT?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejust barely beat\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Q3 earnings estimates yesterday. Our costs were down, but sales fell 4% thanks to people’s continued reluctance to go to the doctor—i.e. fewer prescriptions for our drugs. It’s not just us; they’re \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-27/slow-covid-recovery-stalks-health-industry-as-new-cases-surge?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehaving the same problem\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e over at Eli Lilly. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHerd immunity: \u003c/strong\u003eStock is down. Doctors don’t know yet if antibodies = immunity, but it may not matter. A study published Monday \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/study-shows-covid-19-antibodies-waning-over-time-suggesting-immunity-may-wear-off-11603757012?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshowed\u003c/a\u003e the number of people with antibodies dropped significantly (27%) in a three-month period, indicating that any immunity could be temporary. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe study hasn’t been peer reviewed yet. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe U.S.’ vaccine game is high-stakes. Any slip-ups in the program—such as only four out of six candidates proving effective, or not enough people getting vaccinated—\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-27/all-in-push-for-vaccine-in-u-s-raises-risk-virus-will-linger?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecould mean\u003c/a\u003e we’ll be dealing with the virus well into 2023. But if everything goes smoothly, we could turn the tide by July of next year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ FYI: \u003c/strong\u003eOn Monday, Dr. Anthony Fauci told Yahoo Finance that the “primary endpoint” of a vaccine is “to prevent clinically recognizable disease,” aka stamping out symptoms, rather than eliminating the virus entirely.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen you read every news story published, some numbers stand out. Here's a roundup from yesterday: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1.4 billion: \u003c/strong\u003eThat's how many face masks 3M \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/3m-sales-rise-from-personal-safety-home-improvement-products-11603798292?mod=hp_lead_pos4\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehas sold\u003c/a\u003e so far this year, per its earnings report. The manufacturer is aiming to make 2.4 billion N95 masks annually by the end of the year, which would more than triple its capacity before the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e95%: \u003c/strong\u003ethe year-over-year drop in the number of finishers of timed races between mid-March and mid-October 2020, according to racing platform Athlinks. With major running events canceled all over the world due to the pandemic, the industry is facing its \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronaviruss-toll-on-marathons-and-other-races-a-95-drop-11603800000?mod=hp_listc_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egreatest crisis\u003c/a\u003e in history, the WSJ writes. New York City's (canceled) marathon was supposed to take place this weekend.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1: \u003c/strong\u003eThere was only one chain in the Restaurant Brands International portfolio (Burger King, Tim Hortons, etc.) to report positive same-store sales growth last quarter...can you guess which one? class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egrew 17.4%\u003c/a\u003e in Q3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn case Halloween candy sales in July didn't get the point across, humans are bad at sticking to schedules. Which is why a handful of governments are \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/countries-try-shorter-covid-19-quarantines-in-bid-to-boost-compliance-11603791001?mod=hp_lead_pos6\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshortening quarantines\u003c/a\u003e in hopes that more people will actually start complying, the WSJ reports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e14-day quarantines were reduced to seven days in France, while Belgium, Spain, and Germany are cutting them to 10. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCanada, Thailand, and the U.S. are also considering chopping quarantines for international visitors.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIs this a good idea? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe short answer is, scientists don't have enough data to know. But people aren't following quarantines, and health officials want to try something.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe standard 14-day quarantine isn't perfect science, either. The WHO says the average coronavirus incubation period (time from exposure to feeling sick) is 5–6 days, but for some cases it can take as long as two weeks.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ewith turkey season around the corner, quarantines are more important than ever. Yesterday, NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio \u003ca href=\"https://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/politics/2020/10/27/mondays-with-the-mayor-bill-de-blasio-holiday-travel-message?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003easked\u003c/a\u003e New Yorkers to avoid holiday travel. And many colleges \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/18/spring-break-coronavirus-colleges-429924?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eare sending\u003c/a\u003e students home from campus after Thanksgiving, extending winter break, and scrapping spring break to reduce travel during flu season. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Texas's cities are good for businesses. The WSJ ranked Austin the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/24/austin-tx-tops-wsj-rankings-hottest-us-job-markets?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehottest job market\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in the U.S. for the second straight year in 2019. And tech companies like Apple and Tesla are building new offices and factories in the city like it's their own personal Minecraft server. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat it means for Election Day\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eData compiled by the University of Houston shows that Texas's major metropolitan areas now account for 69% of the statewide vote, up from 52% in 1968. With cities filling fast with young tech workers who broadly lean left, the onetime Republican stronghold has gradually drifted into \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/politics/texas-political-geography/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eswing state\u003c/a\u003e territory. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eIt would still take a historic upswell of Democratic support to flip the state in this election. But as new job seekers continue to reshape its economic landscape, Texas and its meaty 38 electoral college votes might be up for grabs when 2024 rolls around.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis week, Kazakhstan's tourism board released a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/26/business/kazakhstan-embraces-borat.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew advertising campaign\u003c/a\u003e, \"Very nice,\" to capitalize on the buzz around the new \u003cem\u003eBorat \u003c/em\u003esequel.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eBorat, a fictional Kazakh journalist played by Sacha Baron Cohen, has the kind of backward ideas you don't want people associating with your country. So when the original \u003cem\u003eBorat \u003c/em\u003efilm came out in 2006, the government banned the movie and tried to explain Kazakhstan is actually \u003cem\u003enot \u003c/em\u003ea cluster of medieval hamlets, as the film would have you believe.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe nowstory: \u003c/strong\u003eKazakh Tourism released a series of \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eRGXq4t9wY4\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e12-second video spots\u003c/a\u003e that use Borat's famous catchphrase (well, the only G-rated one) to describe the central Asian country's attractions. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"Kazakhstan's nature is very nice, its food is very nice, and its people, despite Borat's jokes to the contrary, are some of the nicest in the world,\" Kairat Sadvakassov, deputy chairman of Kazakh Tourism, said in a statement.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis story reminds us of some other controversial tourism slogans. Rhode Island broadcasted itself as \"\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/07/us/a-new-rhode-island-slogan-encounters-social-medias-wrath.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCooler and Warmer\u003c/a\u003e\" in 2016; two years later, Nebraska \u003ca href=\"https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2018/oct/18/honestly-its-not-for-everyone-says-nebraskas-self-/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e, \"Honestly, it's not for everyone.\"  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
